moves.4. e3 O-O 5. Bd3 d5 6. Nf3 c5 7. O-O b6: I like to fianchetto my bishops if possible. Here it is somewhat delayed.
moves.12. a4 Nc6 13. Ba3 Re8 14. Rb1 Qc7 15. h: It´s still kind of even. White are soon ready to the pawn push e4. This move will also make my c4 pawn weak.
moves.16... Ne4 17. Bxe4 Rxe4: Because I take back with my e-rook instead of the pawn, I´m avoiding to isolate and weaken my c-pawn. I also have some vague ideas about starting an attack against Whites castled King in the future.
moves.18. Qc2 Rde8 19. Ng5: Now begins the trickiest part of the game, with much threats and counterthreats, and maneuvers back and forth!
moves.23. e4: Now the long anticipated pawn push gets a reality. Tricky position.
moves.23... Be6: After a long pondering I find this the best move.
moves.24. e5: This move is not so pleasant for me. White gains space here. Probably better for White was exd5. I can´t take back with my Bishop, if I do that I loose my e-Rook! White probably missed that!
moves.29... h6: But I can live with that. For now I begin to impose a serious threat against Whites King.
moves.40. Rd8+: I was here pondering pretty long time, accept or reject the sacrifice? But decides to take it.
moves.40... Qxd8 41. Rxg4: White wins a Bishop back, but still I´m up in material.
moves.41... Rxg4 42. Qxg4 Nh6: To be a Knight up is always nice. Especially when the endgame is near.
moves.43. Qe4 Qg5+ 44. Kf1 Qc1+ 45. Qe1 Qxe1+: To trade Queens are the easiest way to win.
moves.52... Kd7 53. f4 b5 54. a5 Kc7 55. e6 fx: White gives up. And that is right. He is completely lost now.
